reviewText:
The truth? I was super hyped for this game. FINALLY, a Naruto game came to PC! And since i don't owe any consoles (except for a PS2), i was over-excited to finally skip the Dolphin's Wii emulatons; the PSP imitations, and play it for real. At first, i thought it would be great, since i didn't expect to play online. And boy, was i right about that.
I do'nt have any console controllers, but i managed to make my way through with the keyboard (i literally imitated Mister Sheen: WINNING!), and i felt great until i had pretty much unlocked everything. It soonly started to get boring on SP, so i tried MP. A sad thought crossed my mind after seeing the game have a bad transmission. But still, i could just keep playing with bots, so it was a very small setback.

What keeps my addicted until this day, is a very simple, and perhaps unexpected thing: The Community.
But not the raging quitters, the trolls, the spammers, or the IA Abusers (Neji, i'm looking at you). It was the modders. Modders like wajinshu" in youtube

reviewText:
A fantastic fighter, especially if you are a fan of the manga or show and even if your not. ****Transmission Error's or not.**** Scroll to the comments section to for transmission error fix.

-- Singleplayer --

If you're someone like me who can't sit through 15 seasons of filler and slow paced talking scenes the game does a great job of filling you in on most of what's happened without eating up months of your free time. Even if you have been watching or reading though it also gives you the option of picking the Legend" route on certain fights to experience things differently; a great alternative to experiencing the same thing you've seen before but still progressing. The cut scenes are fantastically done and the option for the Japanese vocal track is always nice as I for one will punch someone if I hear Naruto say "Believe it!" one more time. Of course you are still forced to play as certain characters for certain parts that aren't always fun. Some of the boss battles can also be down right cheap
date: the final one for instance but hey
recommended:
you only have to do it once and that's a small price to pay for how much fun is packed in there.

-- General --

Now for me considering I haven't played an Ultimate Ninja game before this was a welcome change from the Clash of Ninja fighting games
voteText: epic feel of every battle and the sheer complexity of the mechanics was something I wasn't expecting from an Anime fighter. If your looking for a little one on one kick-assery this is a fantastic place to land your feet. It is a little sad that you can't play even a tag mode or something similar
helpfulPercent: the complete lack of co-operative fighting does seem like an oversight considering how entertaining it could be and considering it's something Clash of Ninja has had since the get-go.\n\nOne more key thing to point out as well is the sheer amount of content here
votesHelpful: holy crap the content. There is the massive Story Mode
votesTotal: the bonus Challenge Mode with 100 battles to complete
votesFunny: Survival Mode
commentsCount: Tournament Mode
column16: the regular VS Mode and of course Online Mode. That's a a lot of things to clear. There is also an almost obsurd amount of collectables to unlock and purchase from Titles for your online Ninja Card to Ultimate Jutsu Demonstrations. The game contains 89 (correct me if I'm wrong) playable characters with only a few available as support only
column17: as well as several characters having different costumes. Not counting same movelist
column18: different costumes that seven versions of Sasuke to play as
column19: rejoice Uchiha fans. It will take a while to unlock every character mind you but that can be done by either playing and earning money or clearing the entirety of the massive story mode. So if you don't like running through the sometimes tedious boss battles and the like
column20:
just hop into VS mode and beat the crap out of your friends. Which brings us to the biggest problem - I didn't say the game was perfect.

-- Multiplayer --

The game does a decent job of balancing the massive roster but at the end of the day
column21: some characters are just down right overpowered and cheap. Which can be a problem unless you happen to have mastered the game and the other person hasn't. Roughly 60% of the matches you play online will either be against the ultimate form of Naruto
column22:
Minato or Itachi and there's a reason for that. Not that the cheap characters are unbeatable but unless you're also a high tier character prepare to have an annoyingly difficult fight; oh Itachi your crows will haunt my nightmares. Of course this being said it's not the end of the world by any means. If your fighting your friends or just playing for fun it probably won't bother you and overpowered characters is something you should be expecting going into a fighter with such a massive roster that isn't aiming to be a serious competition game. Virtua Fighter this is not.

****-- Multiplayer Section 2 --**** Scroll to the comments section to for transmission error fix.

Another key thing I have to draw attention to is something that has been completely "broken" about this game since launch: Transmission Error's. For those of you who don't know what this is
column23: it's a disconnection error that occurs in most matches played online
column24: example: I have played roughly 350 matches online
column25: completing only 120 of them. While Namco-Bandai has assured us they are working on it
column26: it has been present since launch and still isn't fixed. They have released a NA only patch for the game that
column27: to it's credit did work somewhat
column28: but instead of getting disconnected in some games we are presented with a slow down kind of lag and even then
column29: sometimes are disconnected anyways. Assuming they do
column30: at some point fix the issue the game will be downright fantastic but until then
column31:
the loyal fan base is left raging every match until you fight someone 30 times because it doesn't disconnect you for once.

-- Final Thoughts --

All in all it's not a perfect game and until they sort out the transmission errors in the online portion
column32: it will be broken for those seeking to use it. However
column33: it still retains a fighting experience that you simply can't get somewhere else. Trying to end an epic battle with an Ultimate Jutsu is so much fun and that terrible moment when you chakra dash right into someone elses costing you the match
column34: leaving you yelling out curses; barely coming out of a match on top thanks to a well timed awakening and realizing you lost by 1/8th a heath bar to Rock Lee and you didn't land a hit on him. Moments like these make you forget about the shortcomings of the game.\n\nIf your looking for a solid fighter pick it up and prepare to lose the next few weeks of your life

reviewText:
When i original saw the trailer for this game, i thought it was a very action/adventure/fighting packed game type, boy i was complete wrong.

You can divide this game in 2 parts, the story side and the vs side.

The story side obviously let you follow trough the story of the anime/manga, starting after the nagato/pain saga, returning from time to time to the 9 tails incident in the leaf 16 years before. However, this is the cool part and the sad one at the same moment. The game (if you can call it that way) has no adventure side, you follow the story in a cinematic/dialogue type, with little to no gameplay (the gameplay limits from going from 1 screen to another, and no more than 3, and this is from time to time), then, after a while, after watching a cinematic or reading the dialiogues, a confrontation between characters will happen, mostly the same fights that happened in the anime/manga. This is your gameplay, a small fight, then you go back to the cinematics/dialogues.

The sad part is that you get so little gampleay that you feel ripped off your money, however, the fighting mechanics, as basic as some button mashing can be, are quite fun, specially if you have teammates with you, which help you in battle (support characters ala mvsc), from time to time you will find some quicktime events, not actually difficult, but they might take you by surprise, since there are not that many. reviewText:
This is game is truly wonderful if you enjoy the Naruto Series, but even if you don't know much about the Series it is still enjoyable beacasue the Ninja World Timeline allows you to catch to up to what happened in the story by playing the extra Missions. The online can be pretty laggy,  but when you find a match your in for a fast paced, action packed fight.

Overall: This game is a great package. Over 80 playable ninjas, deep and intense storyline that leaves you wanting more every chapter, and a battle system that allows for anyone to pick up and play and those who are experinced to pick up and master!

reviewText: GOOD :) This is an AMAZING GAME! Even if you don't like naruto or anime isn't your thing in general then you shouldn't be disheartened because you'll still definitely enjoy the game. The fighting style is very good and unique and you can do some pretty sick moves. The story line is very detailed and not hard at all to understand (Although you should probably read or find out what's happened in the anime before the game's storyline. The game is awesome and a lot better than a lot of the other naruto games in the series, because they have improved the graphics a lot and you can do team ultimate finishers too. Compared to the normal ninja storm 3, full burst has some really amazing graphics in comparison and they have done a very good job of improving the game. They have added new cutscenes and about 100 more missions for the player to complete after completing the main story.\nBAD :( The developers are still trying to bring out several different updates for the game becuase online doesn't work very well, its playable but it glitches a lot. Secondly it's highly recommended to use a gamepad, or you can still use the 'ol keyboard but a mouse isn't compatible with the game (which really fudgin sucks!)\nFinally, they have bought out some new characters that weren't in the other games but they should keep some of the old ones too.

reviewText:
Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 Full Burst is perhaps the most extreme example yet of Namco Bandai's attempt to appeal to the converted and only to the converted. Here's a game not simply for any old Naruto fan, but for Naruto fans who are completely up to date with the story and characters as they currently exist in the anime/manga episodes and are seeking a new way of experiencing previously explored plotlines. If you're not up to date, then not only are you going to struggle enormously with the story as depicted in the game's early stages, but you're going to ruin what you've not yet seen of the TV series. Unfortunately, due to gameplay that is as unwieldy and bloated as its title, Full Burst is not an acceptable way to get yourself up to date with this franchise.
his may be a beat-'em-up, but the primary Ultimate Adventure mode features so little gameplay in comparison to cutscenes and dialogue-heavy exposition that you'd be forgiven for thinking you're sitting through a barely interactive (albeit combat-heavy) soap opera. It feels as though developer CyberConnect2's plan was to create a condensed edition of the anime in which fight scenes are playable, rather than create a game in its own right. This leads to an experience that features such haphazard and irregular pacing that your principal cause for intrigue rests in trying to work out just how long it's going to be before the game asks you to pick up the controller again--and even when you do, the core combat is a shallow, button mashing affair that requires little in the way of skill. While there's definite and worthwhile value in repackaging the events of a beloved series in a new format, there's also value in a game giving you something to do.

There may be a lack of interaction in story mode, but that doesn't hold true for the package as a whole. Including all of the downloadable content released for the original Naruto Shippuden Ultimate Ninja 3 release, the volume of content on offer is gargantuan. Chief among the additions is the extra Ultimate Adventure chapter, which sees Sasuke and Itachi Uchiha take on the nefarious Sage Kabuto, a segment that is so phenomenally difficult in comparison to the rest of the game that all previously learned tactics become essentially redundant. The same Sage Kabuto is unlockable as a playable character if you have the patience to jump through the numerous hoops to unlock him, and there are also some new costumes to swoon over.
he biggest, but certainly not most interesting, piece of extra content comes in the form of supplementary challenge missions. One hundred of these have you beating an opponent in a fight while handicapped in some way--removing your ability to jump, for example, or setting a limit on the number of attacks at your disposal. While these missions do add some welcome variety to the combat, they primarily serve to highlight just how shallow the core mechanics are. Without these externally shoehorned twists on battle, fighting suffers from an overwhelming shallowness that sees you engage autopilot once the basics become second nature. Only during set-piece boss battles are you asked to do something out of the ordinary.

To compound matters, the most members of the enormous character roster plays in the same way. You swap between characters regularly during Ultimate Adventure, but this is done predominantly to facilitate the narrative rather than to spice up gameplay through variety and diversity. Granted, significant and impressive visual flair is achieved by switching often between characters with attacks that are literally out of this world, but that aesthetic quality doesn't remain interesting long enough for the combat inadequacies to be forgiven. Clearly, this is not a game with the remotest desire to cement its place in the bastion of hardcore fighting game legacy, but that doesn't excuse the fact that there's so little meat to the gameplay that you're essentially feasting on elaborately painted bones.

Similar problems exist with Ultimate Adventure's role-playing-game-lite elements, which allow you to roam around a number of different environments with a view to collecting and buying items to use in combat (health potions, strength buffs, and so on) and optionally talking to loitering non-player characters. At times, these moments provide a welcome break from the cutscene/fight/cutscene pattern, but more often than not, they feel designed to artificially lengthen the game and trick you into thinking you're playing something with genuine genre-blending aspirations.
The closest comparison to this format is Asura's Wrath, another of CyberConnect2's offerings. However, where Asura's Wrath succeeds in this style of storytelling thanks to its short length and ferocious pace, Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 suffers from attempting to cover far too much ground for the core mechanics to handle. If you do classify yourself as a Naruto aficionado, then simply having another medium through which to consume the narrative is potentially going to be enough to satisfy you. Without a doubt, everyone else should look elsewhere.

reviewText:
A fantastic fighter, especially if you are a fan of the manga or show and even if your not. ****Transmission Error's or not.**** Scroll to the comments section to for transmission error fix.

-- Singleplayer --

If you're someone like me who can't sit through 15 seasons of filler and slow paced talking scenes the game does a great job of filling you in on most of what's happened without eating up months of your free time. Even if you have been watching or reading though it also gives you the option of picking the Legend" route on certain fights to experience things differently; a great alternative to experiencing the same thing you've seen before but still progressing. The cut scenes are fantastically done and the option for the Japanese vocal track is always nice as I for one will punch someone if I hear Naruto say "Believe it!" one more time. Of course you are still forced to play as certain characters for certain parts that aren't always fun. Some of the boss battles can also be down right cheap
date: the final one for instance but hey
recommended:
you only have to do it once and that's a small price to pay for how much fun is packed in there.

-- General --

Now for me considering I haven't played an Ultimate Ninja game before this was a welcome change from the Clash of Ninja fighting games
voteText: epic feel of every battle and the sheer complexity of the mechanics was something I wasn't expecting from an Anime fighter. If your looking for a little one on one kick-assery this is a fantastic place to land your feet. It is a little sad that you can't play even a tag mode or something similar
helpfulPercent: the complete lack of co-operative fighting does seem like an oversight considering how entertaining it could be and considering it's something Clash of Ninja has had since the get-go.\n\nOne more key thing to point out as well is the sheer amount of content here
votesHelpful: holy crap the content. There is the massive Story Mode
votesTotal: the bonus Challenge Mode with 100 battles to complete
votesFunny: Survival Mode
commentsCount: Tournament Mode
column16: the regular VS Mode and of course Online Mode. That's a a lot of things to clear. There is also an almost obsurd amount of collectables to unlock and purchase from Titles for your online Ninja Card to Ultimate Jutsu Demonstrations. The game contains 89 (correct me if I'm wrong) playable characters with only a few available as support only
column17: as well as several characters having different costumes. Not counting same movelist
column18: different costumes that seven versions of Sasuke to play as
column19: rejoice Uchiha fans. It will take a while to unlock every character mind you but that can be done by either playing and earning money or clearing the entirety of the massive story mode. So if you don't like running through the sometimes tedious boss battles and the like
column20:
just hop into VS mode and beat the crap out of your friends. Which brings us to the biggest problem - I didn't say the game was perfect.

-- Multiplayer --

The game does a decent job of balancing the massive roster but at the end of the day
column21: some characters are just down right overpowered and cheap. Which can be a problem unless you happen to have mastered the game and the other person hasn't. Roughly 60% of the matches you play online will either be against the ultimate form of Naruto
column22:
Minato or Itachi and there's a reason for that. Not that the cheap characters are unbeatable but unless you're also a high tier character prepare to have an annoyingly difficult fight; oh Itachi your crows will haunt my nightmares. Of course this being said it's not the end of the world by any means. If your fighting your friends or just playing for fun it probably won't bother you and overpowered characters is something you should be expecting going into a fighter with such a massive roster that isn't aiming to be a serious competition game. Virtua Fighter this is not.

****-- Multiplayer Section 2 --**** Scroll to the comments section to for transmission error fix.

Another key thing I have to draw attention to is something that has been completely "broken" about this game since launch: Transmission Error's. For those of you who don't know what this is
column23: it's a disconnection error that occurs in most matches played online
column24: example: I have played roughly 350 matches online
column25: completing only 120 of them. While Namco-Bandai has assured us they are working on it
column26: it has been present since launch and still isn't fixed. They have released a NA only patch for the game that
column27: to it's credit did work somewhat
column28: but instead of getting disconnected in some games we are presented with a slow down kind of lag and even then
column29: sometimes are disconnected anyways. Assuming they do
column30: at some point fix the issue the game will be downright fantastic but until then
column31:
the loyal fan base is left raging every match until you fight someone 30 times because it doesn't disconnect you for once.

-- Final Thoughts --

All in all it's not a perfect game and until they sort out the transmission errors in the online portion
column32: it will be broken for those seeking to use it. However
column33: it still retains a fighting experience that you simply can't get somewhere else. Trying to end an epic battle with an Ultimate Jutsu is so much fun and that terrible moment when you chakra dash right into someone elses costing you the match
column34: leaving you yelling out curses; barely coming out of a match on top thanks to a well timed awakening and realizing you lost by 1/8th a heath bar to Rock Lee and you didn't land a hit on him. Moments like these make you forget about the shortcomings of the game.\n\nIf your looking for a solid fighter pick it up and prepare to lose the next few weeks of your life
column35: and bring some friends. If your looking for a competitive fighting experience
column36: best to wait till the fix the online before investing. But either way

reviewText:
This game is one of the best fighting/ anime games so far. There are lots of characters to play with and they all have a unique style so the gamplay is endless.

Campaign:
It follows the actual anime and it has enough side missions to spend time on after the main story has ended. These extra stories also unluck new pictures, substitution items, etc... even a survival mode where you can train your skills with your favourite characters.

Online:
Though there are a lot of idiotic persons out there, who find it funny to just camp and counter/ spam and be irritating, there are also players who want to have a great battle with you. These guys will maybe give you a hard time but with them you will be able to really learn the basics.
Also the internet connection/ lag can occur quit often, though you will quickly find someone that doesnt lag and hey just add them to your friends list. I have got quite a couple active non-lagging players who I can play regularly with.

Overall an amazing game, just find the right good-minded jplayers who are willing to help you and play fair and this game will keep you buzy for a long time.

reviewText: As you know already Naruto Shippuden is a 1 on 1 fighting game . All that fighting and action is totally awesome BUT if you dont know a thing about naruto i.e. if you dont follow anime or manga the cutscenes and the story will be tediously boring. You will fell that the charcter keep blabbering on and on as if you were listening to your history teacher in the class whos talking in slow motion . Mind you the combined time required to see all the cutscenes is more than 7 hours (that might be more than the gameplay time if skip the cutscenes) ! Whereas most games have a total of 2-3 hrs (even the game of the name is soo long) . You will be vexed out out of pure boredom if you watch the cutscenes without any knowledge about anime or manga of naruto. So if you have no interest in naruto i suggest you skip all the cutscenes and enjoy the thrill of this breathtaking fighting game . However if you wish to see the cinemtic the i suggest you first follow up on narutos anime and manga on the net. This formidable game feature a colossal number of perplexing characteres and fighting moves.... i didnt even know what a jutsu is before i played this game. I thereby conclude by saying that Naruto Shippuden ultimate ninja storm burst 3 : full burst"( is there a half burst?) is simply astoshing and bewildering even though the cinemtaic is too long ."

reviewText:
Single player flawlessly delivers the over the top eye candy moments that most have come to expect from the Storm series, but the online multiplayer mode holds this game back.

While the fighting mechanics are just a sound as they were in previous Storm games, the game's online components arrives broken at best. The game is currently plagued with large amounts of disconnection errors and matchmaking issues that make finding a reliable opponent a real hassle. A large majority of players are experiencing game ending transmission errors that make online play near impossible to play outside of the few rare occurences the game decides to actually let you and your oppenent carry out an entire match.

If you're a Naruto fan the game's over the top single player should be enough to satisfy your mystical ninja cravings, just don't expect to start duking it out online without a little bit of patience and a whole lot of luck.

reviewText:
Without a doubt my favorite anime fighter to date. Has a lot of content to keep replay value alive, combat is simple and intense meaning it's easy for new comers to pick up and enjoy, story while not exactly accurate to the manga and anime (Looking at you Kage vs Madara fight) still well told, absolutley beautiful visuals, an eargasmic soundtrack, incredible bosses and in the first 5 minutes completely trumping where Dragon Sword Chronicles failed miserably this is defintly a game that can satisfy a fan of Naruto or a fan of anime in general. For those of you who are fighting game fanatics I suggest looking at gameplay first before jumping in just in case the mechanics are your thing.

The only thing I can say needs improvement is the lip sync for the english voices is still pretty off. I know it's synced to the original japanese audio but I feel it could have been edited to fit the english voice. Hell it's like that for multiplayer.

Regarless this is still a great game. Defintly worth the wait.

reviewText: Breaks the mold of usual Naruto fighting games with some nice 360 degree combat in which you can actually use tactics *le gasp*. But seriously, the single player mode is pretty good, even if it is a railroad of cutscenes, limited environments outside of battle and scripted fights every now and then. The combat makes up for all it's flaws in my opinion and is well worth a look if you are into Naruto stuffs or just want a colourful fight-em-up.

reviewText:
Overall this game is extremely good from a standpoint of how fun it is, when it works. With ongoing issues coming up with the server, in put lag, the still not yet defeated transmission errors,  and in my opinion a faulty connection system. This game is one of my favorites even along side all these issues, and within the month I've had it, my play time has surpassed everything  except Dota 2. Passing Borderlands 2, Terraria, and Skyrim. This game is extremely fun, and fluid fighting game who defines itself in it's own personal touch. Regardless of having a single 'attacking' ability this game still manages to maintain a decently high skill cap whereas you won't see a player who is obviously more inexperienced than you taking games off of you for silly things, while it is usually the case that doesn't disregard the fact that it is easily possible.

Along with the the fun gameplay comes obnoxious mechanics that have extremely low skill cap and can remove  a lot of the fun from the match, with awakenings like susanoo and fuu to obnoxious characters with Instant awakening resets like Asuma or Neji. In the end, i'll recieve more anguish from losing an obviously won match to a silly awakening or such than dominating a strong playe.

While this game has it's issues with server and silly low skill cap easily accessible mechanics, I still recommend this game due to, while being short, maintaining an extremely fun story line and when working fun  multiplayer combat. I feel if CC2 provides proper patching this game could be more than just 'good'. ^^

reviewText:
I have played enough of this game, and I think Its time to write review about it.
I recommend this game for all fighting genre lovers!
Lets start with good things:
+ Amazing Storyline, If you don't want to watch anime, you will understand what happened in hundreds of episodes just by playing this game, Of course some things are changed in Naruto Storm 3 Story compared to the original Anime.

+ Great Graphics, If you enable SuperSampling on 2X, The game Is gorgeous.

+ A lot of Playable Characters.

+ Adventure Mode(In story mode) Is really enjoyable, There are a lots of missions to keep you busy.

+ Online mode, You can fight against your friends, or someone who you don't know.

+ All dlcs are In this package, Simply you purchase the base game, And you have all dlcs.

+ Uchiha brothers story Is Implanted, To unlock It you have to do few tasks which takes time, But In the end, It does worth it.


Now the bad things:
- Online mode has few problems.

- 30fps lock

- Adventure mode might get boring for you, Because mostly you go from point A, to point B.

- It would be nice to have locked support characters as playable characters.

- Cutscenes are long, But It Isn't con for me, For most people It should be.

- There are lots of unnecessary loading pauses.

- Some of the characters hasn't been updated since Storm 2.

- Sometimes camera bugs out.

- Sometimes you will notice glitches.

Overall I recommend this game for fighting genre lovers, And mostly for Anime: Naruto Shippuden watchers.

I rate It 8/10 and recommend buying this on sale, Because last game of Storm franchise arrived already, and If you watch Anime: Naruto Shippuden, You may think storyline Is kinda outdated compared to the current anime storyline.

reviewText:
Naruto Shippuden Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 Full Burst is a great fighter, once it finally clicks. When you start the story nothing is explained and you start with a pretty hectic battle, which can rather easily be won with just some button mashing. After that comes a frustratingly long battle if you have no idea what you're doing. It took me over 40 minutes to finally beat this enemy, and by that time I understood the controls slightly better. When I was halfway into the game I was still figuring things out. It would've been nice if there was some sort of tutorial; the loading screens show moves and tips but half of the time they disappear way too quickly to properly read them.

As I said, it's a great fighter with amazing visuals and cinematics (although they're a bit too long) and a bit of (linear) freedom where you can accept sidequests, find 'secrets', eat food to heal your crew and buy items that you can use during your battles.

Battles are usually relatively easy and if they're not the checkpoints seem rather limited. It took me several tries to finish the last battle, with is actually pretty long (10-20 minutes). All because it didn't have enough checkpoints. The easier battles had more checkpoints, but weren't usually needed. I thought that was a bit weird... Could be me, though.

The camera can also get in the way at times, but thankfully you can swing it the other way with the press of a button. Simple enough, but still noteworthy.

Unfortunately, I had to skip most of the cinematics (they're uncountable, there are so many). Why ? I've never seen a single episode of this show, I have only heard of it. It's not a very newbie friendly game if you're new to the show or the game. I normally watch all cinematics but I didn't understand any of it. There are so many characters and the storyline seems to be all over the place, especially at the beginning of the game. I do know that you'll be skipping at least three cinematics every 5 minutes. They just keep coming, it's unbelievable. I don't mean this in a negative way; other fighters should take note ;) I just wish I had seen some of the episodes to know what it's all about.
Behind all of the cinematics there's still enough gameplay to keep you occupied for at least a good 10 hours. Don't skip any of the movies and you can add several hours to that number. Even after finishing the game you can still finish your active sidequests, or accept new ones/ones that you hadn't found yet.

The visuals are amazing. I guess the game looks (and sounds) practically the same as the TV show. Most of the times I couldn't figure out if I was watching gameplay or a cinematic. It all works very fluently, and looks amazing. Some of the QTE battles are just gorgeous ! It's just a shame that all of this is capped to 30FPS, which is absolutely noticeable when you're not fighting, but running around in the environments.

In the end Naruto really impressed me. A lot. It just took about one hour to figure it out. It's a fun and solid game with amazing graphics, and if you love fighters, or Naruto, this game is a must. More please.

[Rating: 79/100]

reviewText:
I'd like to establish that I'm not a Naruto fanâ€” I couldn't careless about the series.
Now, in Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 the story is presented in a way that those who don't follow the manga or anime could still enjoy it.
Action packed quick time events will keep your attention laced into the game in between fast-paced battles. Amazing sound tracks that fit right into the atmosphere will allow you to easily be absorbed into the atmosphere; the mixture of visual and auditory elements that compliment each other gives this game a great mark in the artistically inclined" department.
If you enjoy the general artistic anime style Naruto brings then this game is a must.
If you enjoy the series then this game is a must.
If you enjoy using spectacular over-the-top moves then this game is a must.
The following are pros and cons to the game.

Pros:
Fantastic artic presentation
One of the few anime[ish] games on steam
Great music
Over the top moves
Fast paced
Many characters to chose from
Many things to unlock

Cons
The melee system could've been given a bit more attention.
The online battles may be filled with spamming

reviewText: Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 Full Burst is perhaps the most extreme example yet of Namco Bandai's attempt to appeal to the converted and only to the converted. Here's a game not simply for any old Naruto fan, but for Naruto fans who are completely up to date with the story and characters as they currently exist in the anime/manga episodes and are seeking a new way of experiencing previously explored plotlines. If you're not up to date, then not only are you going to struggle enormously with the story as depicted in the game's early stages, but you're going to ruin what you've not yet seen of the TV series. Unfortunately, due to gameplay that is as unwieldy and bloated as its title, Full Burst is not an acceptable way to get yourself up to date with this franchise.

reviewText:
Only for hardcore Naruto fans.

PROS:

+ great presentation
+ controls(easy to learn, hard to master)
+ MASSIVE character roster
+ all characters feel unique
+ ultimate abilities

CONS:

- the cutscenes are LONG(this could be a PRO if you're into the franchise)
- the camerawork
- difficulty balance is off
- some characters are overpowered while others pathetically useless
- if you know nothing about the manga/anime, the story will be confusing

UNS 3 is really easy on the eyes.
Plenty of characters to choose from, they suit multitude of playstyles.
There's multiplayer, local vs mode, pretty long single player campaign with extra end-game content.
Sounds great, no?
However, once you start playing, little nuisances start chipping away at your patience.
To the point that you may stop playing and give up on finishing the game entirely.
Happened to me a couple of times during my gameplay(I'm looking at you, Deidara, YOU PIECE OF â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥).
And, mark my words, the final battle is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing joke(the camerawork during that one added an insult to injury, it's almost as if the devs implemented a clunky camera on purpose).
I'm all in for difficult games, but difficult as in challenging but fair"

reviewText:
If there were less issue with onlnie, the game would have been great, it's just badly optimized. On another side, it's the first Naruto game on PC, and the last i played was Gekitou Ninja Taisen 4 on GC, that tells about it, i'm not a regular of Naruto games, but a fan of the manga. Fights are dynamics, different options of combos and few ninjutsus (too few, but how do you wanna code multiple on one character, no wonder there are 4 naruto and sasuke..), use of items, tournament (only fun if online works), sweet visual, and a GREAT story mode, that reproducts pretty nicely the manga (aside of some obsolete fights).

I'm not really upset to have buy it full price; understand this is a great fighting game for any Naruto fans, but they really have to do something with the online transmission issue, cause the fun is specially here.

I hope and expect a patch, and will wait for Naruto Shippuden UNS Revolution coming out in the next few months.

reviewText: This game has an amazing cinematic feel to it when you are engaged in the important aspects of the story and combat. However, the open world sections are terrible compared to those present on ninja storm 1. They only serve to slow the pace and ruin the mood you had from the epicness that likely occurred moments before. The game is easy to learn but it is definitely difficult to learn the small techniques and habits required to block and perform advanced maneuvers with good reaction time. Overall, the game is simple and fun. You don't need to follow the anime to play this game and the cutscenes go through pretty much all of the episodes in this arc while leaving out the filler. That does not make it as good as the anime though.

reviewText:
I am finding I love this game. I will summarize my situation so you can compare to yours:

I watched Naruto (Not Shippuden) to completion in High School. I watched about 20-30 episodes of Shippuden then ended up losing interest. I have not watched more than 1 or 2 random Shippuden episodes since and don't really intend to.

I always liked both the Dragon Ball Z games and Naruto games not just for the characters, but also becuase they generally offer a unique type of fighting game you can't really get elsewhere.

With these two things in mind, Ninja Storm 3 is entertaining me greatly.
If you see any of yourself in my summary of myself, I would say to consider getting this game. It is a high quality Naruto Shippuden game that will entertain you if read this far without getting disgusted!

reviewText:
Having followed the series since it was released i was really excited to play this on PC. The game is heavily reliant on closed fights and could have done with a more open, free flowing enviroment. > Great character set.
> Plenty of game time.

Negatives:

7/10.

reviewText:
Im going to review this pretty quickly from a Non-Naruto fan, now I have watched Naruto but no where near that of a fan. This game simply put is amazing, any fighting game should consider playing through this at least once and also checking out the multiplayer.

The story is both engaging and beautifully animated, as I streamed this live on twitch my viewers even commented on how great the game looked. There's plenty of characters to keep you occupied in the other modes too.

The sounds are really crisp, the voice acting is really well done, and if you want that authentic feel you can switch to Japanese voices.

The actual fighting side of the game is extremely fair, and pretty well balanced, it took me a few hours to get to grips with all the Jutsu and counter systems, but once there you start to pull off nice combos and also figure out some strategies to taking out the enemies in front of you.

I grabbed this in the steam sale for Â£6 but if id of paid Â£25 for this I still would of been very happy. I would recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText:
UNS3 is a strong fighter in it's own right, but also a good pick for people like me who more often than not, just don't enjoy fighters. This game has a very Beat-em' up feel to it.. it's also very simple by nature, with simple controls, combos and easy to perform moves. With that said, it has enough depth in the way that you can use those simple moves and turn it into a truly exciting game, full of satisfaction and devious trickery.

This game shines most in it's multiplayer. The best way to experience this game would be locally, with a mate or seven. Failing that, you can of course take to the online mode. The netcode looks like it needs work but disconnects are a thing of the past- the real beast to worry about is latency. Fighting any friend further than my own state (Western Australia) resulted in anywhere between a few milliseconds to half a second of latency, with those in my state being as responsive as a local match. Unfortunately, and this is likely due to poor Australian internet but it's still worth noting, playing any friend overseas was unplayably laggy, resulting in only frustration for both players. It kind of draws from the game, but it's more of an issue for us here.
When you do get connected, it is undoubtedly the most fun part of the game.

That is of course not to say the single player doesn't excel too, oh it does. One of the best stories in a fighting game in thanks to the rich and interesting world provided by the Naruto franchise. The story itself takes place in the same arc the currently-airing anime does at time of release, the Fourth Great Ninja War. The story is solid, it has many moments that will blow your mind and a lot of them are fully playable. Each fight is as memorable as the last, nothing feels too forced or unnecessary and the pace is set nicely too, with the exception of an almost hour-long scene that just sucks the life out of the middle of the game for a while. If I were to pick some nits I'd say that the characters are a bit too stiff and they don't move during dialogue unless it's a big scripted cutscene, but when things get good, they get fantastic. Even flashbacks are implemented into story fights as you play, giving you some GREAT perspective. Some of the story is very simpified, and it focuses more on the Main characters than the Anime does, leaving out some very interesting and emotionally impacful backstory.. but it does the job. It teaches you how to play, offers hours of entertainment and will make you excited for the franchise all over again. Sadly, the ending is a little different to what happens in canon Naruto, likely to avoid spoiler territory for the anime, and thus is a little unsatisfying. It'd be nice to have gotten that little surprise at the end- for that, I highly urge you to watch the anime, the person behind that mask.. ooh! Amazing.

For a Console port, it has it's issues. There's a lack of tweakable options.. you're given a choice of resolution and Anti-Aliasing and that's about it. With that said.... the game runs very smoothly, even at it's locked 30 Frames Per Second, and the Anti-Aliasing does it's job well, there's a very noticable difference and the quality is greatly improved over it's console counterparts, especially in just how smooth and clear the lines are, it helps solidify the feeling this is an Anime. It doesn't really Feel" like a port
date: if that makes sense- while you're playing it
hoursPlayed: sounds great and controls great while running smoother than butter on any decent machine.\n\nWith all that said

reviewText:
The game itself was awsomely converted from console to the PC. Everything is smooth. The Combat system is easy to learn and understand. The graphics during cut scenes and during battle are awesome. The Controller also works perfectly especially when in Direct Input. I also tried it playing with my keyboard which came out to be not to far from the game experience while playing with a controller. The Roster is pretty big too.

What lack here is the ability to customize the matches. The life bar is so short, it makes player's battle experience hang on tenterhooks, especially on versus mode with your friends. The moves are also pretty repetitive. They also removed the ability to customize the ninjutsu used by the player.

But overall. It is a very awesome game that will surely be enjoyed by yourself or with your friends.

reviewText:
Oh. My. God.

This game is amazing, it truly is. The story is really stunning, the characters are really charimastic and the gameplay is really fluid.

Not in online though. You will probably find yourself in situations when you can't  do  anything because of the lag.
Lag only occurs in few matches, and normally is barely noticeable.

There were few people online, now it's very populated, especially at night and in the evening. The game is kind of balanced, with a few chars that are kind of broken (Kisame, EMS Sasuke)

If you don't like playing online you will still like the story. I enjoyed it and I didn't even watch naruto anime or read the manga.

TL;DR: This game is my favourite out of the storm series, buy it, it's really worth it.

reviewText: I bought this game with the thought of just beating up some baddies with amazing jutsu. But boy, it was a lot more than that. I really enjoyed the storyline and fighting mechanics; and my favorite part: all the characters are OP. They all have their unique abilities and are all super fun to play. The art and animation is beautiful as well. Also, I would recommend playing this game with a controller. While using a keyboard is fully viable (I'm using keyboard), I feel that using a controller would be much easier. If you're using keyboard, I would suggest looking for a comfortable configuration, one such as this: http://gyazo.com/4a1035b5d49dfd9f9dfe5859e29e61a4\n\nNinjas are cool. 10/10
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Game's 55% cutscenes, 40% fighting battles & 5% of running about in the campaign. Afterall, this is still a game based off Naruto, an anime/manga. Fighting mechanics are incredibly fun, dialogues are a bit meh on different levels.. Honestly not really a huge fan of the art style too, characters don't really look too much like the ones in the anime show imo. Overall the game's not a let-down, don't get me wrong!

reviewText:
Great game, the best fighting game i've played. First off you don't have to be a hardcore Naruto fan to buy this game; Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm 3's potrayal of the story is stunning, far better than the anime.

Pros: Excellent story, it will keep you on edge of your seat
Great gameplay, easy to get used to yet difficult to master
Graphics are fantasic, there's even Anti-aliasing options

Cons: Requires higher end computers to run smoothly
Minor character balancing issues
Online Multiplayer is..awful, you'll experience a lot of lag.

9/10

reviewText: If you are a fan of Naruto, and haven't played the previous Ninja Storm games but are fairly up to date with the manga or anime then quickly pick this game up today. I say it's well worth it, the story mode is linear, the English VO work is a little weak, but over all the fighting mechnics in the game are fun in their own right. It's nothing new from the previous Ninja Storm games, but if this is your first foray the camera might need a little getting used to. But once you do it's very fun. Also the ninjitsu's and ultimate-jitsu's are extremely entertaining to watch. And honestly there are very little button combos to remember if any really at all. Simple and flashy.

reviewText: Not a fan of fighting games, even a little.  That said, this is more like a action-strategy brawler than a fighting game. For gameplay, 10/10, I played for fifteen minutes and this game went on my favorites.

If you're a big-time Naruto fan and you're looking to buy this as your first Naruto game then I'd definately get it. The story is really fun and the combat is very addicting. You'll enjoy playing as all the different characters and checking out all the jutsu. The online is somewhat broken right now because of connection issues but you can still find people where you don't lag. I'd definately get the second controller out and play with a friend if you can.

*NOTE THAT YOU NEED A WIRED XBOX CONTROLLER TO BE ABLE TO PLAY*

The downside is that you can start to get bored of this game quickly depending on who you are.
The game might not be worth the original $40. I'd wait until it goes on sale before buying it.
You should get at least 30 hours out of it. If you're really addicted to it then that number can go way higher.

reviewText: The last Naruto Ultimate Ninja game I played was 3 on the ps2. I have enjoyed the series quite a bit, as it is one of my favorite 3d fighting game series to date. Now, for this one in particular, the game is very good. Unfortunately the port is not. My biggest gripes are no video options beyond anti-aliasing, screen size, v-sync, or windowed mode, the game is locked at 30 fps with no option in configs to up it to 60, and the online is extremely laggy if you can even find an opponent, which you won't. Also, while you can play with the keyboard, it is not recommended as the port was designed with controllers in mind. On the upside, the story is good. Now, I haven't kept up in the series for awhile so I had no clue what was going on, I was enjoying the ride it took me on. Characters are unlocked for multiplayer as you proceed, and there are plenty to unlock along the way. The actual gameplay is solid. You have a very simple combat style, which one button for melee, a button for ranged, block, dodge (if you have the chakra), awakenings (second forms/power ups) for most of the character, and every character has a ninjutsu and ultimate jutsu to choose from. The characters play very differently. I have found my favorites already, but it's fun to go and play all of the characters as I unlock them to see what they do. Although, if you get sick of playing against bots, you will need some actual friends. Overall, the game is great but it could have been a much better port. 7/10

reviewText:
No idea why so many complain that it is a poor port to PC.....To me the 30fps is not a big issue at all....I am using an extremely high end gaming machine and have no problems with the frame rates whatsoever....It runs perfectly fine...smooth as silk...and i don't see how ramping up the frame rates would help at all....

Read up that some people have problem running this game using AMD processor, you can skip this game if you are not able to run it, but if you can run this game. Not playing it would be one of your biggest regret...

Playing it using a Xbox 360 controller and it is one of the best fighting games i have played for a long time considering that i have played tons of fighting games before. There are tons of characters to choose from. The main campaign is awesome and captivating. I have no problem with the online battles as well. Seem like it is so much better after their patch. All in all, this is one game i don't mind paying full price if need be.

reviewText:
A story about teenagers who team up with grown-ups to fight other evil teenagers and grown-ups.
They have magical powers originating from this guy called Nin Ja who trained warriors, and they use his Jutsu (techiniques) to battle each other.
Nin taught them how to use this magical goo called 'Chakra' which they store inside themselves and depending on their personalities it turns into things like fire, lightning, water, dirt, lava, bubbles, coral, and even Laser beams.

The game is pretty fun, the graphics are just like anime (reminds me of Appleseed), and original Japanese Voiceovers are available (much better than the generic english VAs)

Cons I found:
I 100%'d this game but for some reason I still have a couple achievements that I didnt get >:[

Some characters take up multiple character slots when they don't need to, seriously Choji takes two just so he can put on his combat jacket, and there is FOUR slots each for Naruto and Sasuke.
They could have taken that realestate and used it for the characters they took out like the sound ninjas, Anko, Kurenai, etc. or they couldve finished off the characters and made them playable like the mist swordsmen or the edo-tensei kages.

Online is only good with people in your country (or at least close) and doesnt even try to match you up with someone with good ping. (I generally couldnt care less since I don't like playing with strange internet creeps anyway, but there you have it)

They only offer SuperSampling AA, which is a waste of gpu power when simple MS, CS, FX, SM or what ever AA you want is a better option.

9/10, Fun, Good looking, true to the anime (until the end, they made up an ending instead of saying 'to be continued')

^

reviewText:
Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja STORM 3 Full Burst is, in typical fighting game tradition, an updated version of of Ninja Storm 3. I'll start by saying that that I have not played that game, my point of comparison is the 2nd game.

Combat consists on either 1 on 1 or team on team (1 character and 2 assists) fighting on a 3D plane. The offensive game consists of performing simple attack combos based on a single button and tilt, a guard breaking throw move, throwing and useing various items, and activating special finishing moves by charging up. On the defensive end the options are movement, blocking, and specific to the series Substitution Jutsu which avoid an attack and place the player behind his oppenent. The Substitution has four uses that recharge over time. In low level play this perhaps dumbs down the combat to the player who attacks first on equal substitutions coming out out with a combo but I'll leave that discussion to hardcore players.

Performance wise the game leaves much to be desired. While it is colorful and good-looking for the most part, the lack of graphical options is disappointing. The game is locked at 30 fps, which seems a poor descision for a 3D fighter. These point to little care being put into the PC port.

Coming from Ninja Storm 2 the story mode is huge improvement. Fans of the series will welcome how long and detailed it goes, though sometimes the cutscenes are long.  Having read the series since being as young teenager I've really lost interest in the series, reading weekly as a habit rather than a desire. That being said the game was able to bring emotions to some scenes that the manga failed to do for me. To me that is something very special and a spectacular success. Some story battles have extra moments activated by performing certain actions and performing QTEs. In the context of the story mode this was actually pretty interesting.

Playing a bit online did not show a comunity as active as I thought it would be. As with any fighting game, coming in a few months later left me completely out of the meta, getting my â™¥â™¥â™¥ handed to me by everyone playing as the 4th Hokage. The lag in game is TERRIBLE. But honestly anime based games are not serious fighters, and it is a hell of a lot of fun to play with friends.

If you like the series and have people to play with, get the game. Everyone else might benefit from a demo to see if its for them.

reviewText:
What could be a fun game ruined by a really bad port.

I'm not really a fan of the Naruto Manga/Anime but I always enjoyed the games, for some reason Naruto (as well as DBZ) games always seemed to range from decent to top notch. So I saw this game on sale, and I decided to pick it up.

I can tell it's not a bad game, but holy hell it's a very bad port. Let us make a list on important features it's missing
-No Graphic Options other than Screen Size (made the game nearly unplayable for me).
-Game has no PC controls, you have to make them yourself.
-Even if you put them in, the game still shows the Xbox control promps.

I heard it was a bad port, but...not this bad.

reviewText: Recommended for Naruto fans. If you're not a Naruto fan, but you're looking for a good Beat 'Em Up! game then maybe give this game a try. Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 has no default controls for the keyboard, you'll have to manually set every corresponding key to the controller controls, HOWEVER you can search up various setups other players have put up which can make it alot more fluid to play. If you have a controller yourself however, then I'd recommend you'd use that. The story is based off the Naruto anime so if you don't watch Naruto, you may find the story a bit confusing as it skips some important details.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I came to this game looking for something where I can dip in here and there to have a bit of fun. What I got was much more than that, providing a game that appeals whether you have an interest in the anime/manga or not. NS:UNS3FB contains the awesome drop in and play experience I wanted, providing a large pool of characters which all have their unique traits but the control setup makes them easy to adjust to. It also backs this up with substantial single player modes, ensuring that I put in quite a number of hours exploring everything the game had to offer.

The battle system forgos the usual 1 on 1 fighting style for a behind character more open battle system. Control inputs are quite simple but still offer quite a wide variety of options when fighting, most of which tie into the chakra meter which you have to recharge during battle. Choosing when to unleash that ultimate jutsu or skilfully using a substitute to escape a powerful attack is great fun. Unfortunately the camera has some odd quirks, especially if you get designated as player 2.

You can read a full review of this game here.[www.neoseeker.com]

reviewText:
Before anything

Yes I like this game and yes I am still going to play it and start playing more online.

But I can not say I would pay $40 for this.

Yes I got this game on sale and I think it is worth the $25


Graphics - Great for the style of the game, Colorful

UI - Simple, Artistic, Easy to use.

Sound - Have good headset/speakers and it sounds amazing

Controls - Great (With controler dont know about KB havnt used)

Gameplay - Easy, Fast, interactive in game cutscenes

Playable Characters - Way to many there are what 80 characters to chose from in the game not to mention almost all them have different outfits.

Story - Well I havn't watched much of the TV show so I can't really say. But the story wasn't to bad explaned things as i kept playing the game. You can sometimes chose 2 different out comes in some parts of the story.

World - You can Free roam but you dont really use it much until you beat the game. I feel it was just added in the game. Lots of linear areas and lots of small one to so constant load run for 5 secs then load the next area.

Multiplayer - Yes, Custimizable profile (cards), Leaderboards and ranking system

Bugs? - Well the game has been running perfect for me so no bugs atm

Fun? - Fighting yes, Story yes (sometimes for me), Me having to run to the next area no in the terrible Free roaming system no (thank god it only takes like 30 secs to run to the next area tho).

reviewText: As a Naruto fan, I have to say: there's just too many cutscenes. If the story wasn't about naruto, I'd never play this. You barely get to fight 3 minutes before you have to wait 20min worth of cutscenes to play again. Also, so many useless lines! Producers need to learn from Valve how to tell a story without interrupting the game all the time. Also, the game has pretty much nothing extra compared to the manga or the anime, so no bonus story. And  you have to play storymode if you want to unlock every other character, so you have no choice. You need to go through what's bad about this game before you get to enjoy it. And they probably don't give a damn about it, since it sells easily after the story is already successful. Only buy this if it's on sale, or else it's wasted money. It's a fun game on PvP, but the storymode is a complete desaster.

reviewText: As someone who played some of the previous Ninja STORM titles, Full Burst" takes two steps forward and one step backward... all the while having a deadweight called "online mode" clamped down on its ankle.\n\nGameplay is broken into three parts - story mode
date:
versus mode and online mode. Here are some highlights and lowlights for each mode.

Story Mode Highlights
- Multiple battles with new characters
- Boss battles with quicktime events continue to be visually stunning
- Has a little bit of a "choose your adventure" vibe to the story

Story Mode Lowlights
- Story telling continues to be weak in distribution - subtitles are boring and most of the cinematics involve scrolling stillshots
- Fights can get tedious - there's only so much variation you can do in this game
- Final few boss modes are incredibly frustrating as poor camera angles ruin the fun

---

Versus Mode Highlights
- The real star of the game
recommended: more playable characters than ever\n- Action continues to be fast-paced
hoursPlayed:
great art direction
- Adding cinematics on ultimate skill takedowns adds a bit of flair to fights
- Challenge mode is pretty fun in a mindless sort of way

Versus Mode Lowlights
- Several characters are carry overs from the previous title
voteText: making their skills outdated in comparison to story mode progression\n- Some characters missing from story mode for no reason\n- Balancing issues
helpfulPercent:
certain characters standard attacks can hit you even if you spam log

--

Online Mode Highlights
- It allows you to play with people online

Online Mode Lowlights
- Net code is absolutely terrible. Ridiculous input delay makes the game nearly unplayable.
- Very low online population. The people who do play are veterans with hundreds of hours - you will get wiped.
- Items are not standardized and reflect larger balancing issues.

--

Overall
votesHelpful: I can't recommend buying this game with the next one coming out next month. Unless you REALLY want to play some Naruto goodness right away
votesTotal: hold off for the next iteration which will have three times more characters and some real development on the versus mode side. But don't hold your breath for better online - this is clearly not a priority.\n"

reviewText:
Must buy....really solid game.....

EDIT: I started playing this game again, (When I wrote the review, I only played about 5% of the story) and I have to say im just completely blown away from the polish, story, music, and last but not last gameplay. This game just might move into my top 10 stories of all time for video games.

I have no idea about nartuo, I honestly thought it was a little kids series....but its not.

The story in this game is just simply amazing, the voices (I listen in jap) are amazing graphics and effects I would assume are just like the show. Its just so well done. I wish I was a fan of the show I would be going nuts over this game.

The QTEs....Ive never seen QTE work so well in a video game....this game makes me want to do more QTE. Its just sooooo epic....the system it uses is perfect as well....the better you do....you unlock a secert part of the cutscene....so even if you suck...you dont have to restart or anything (i think, i never failed the qte so im not sure). They just did it right when it comes to QTE.

The story....wow...moved me in ways i dont feel comfortable talking about on steam :P

The story combined with the AAA music just makes your emotions go insane....its really remarkable!

Just a great game....I will make sure to purchase all further nartuo titles.....also going to look into the TV series....

reviewText:
This game already simply amazing when it came out.
Here's is what's good about this game:
â—˜ Amazing Story but went different from the actual show(Naruto Shippuden) still amazing.

â—˜ Awesome music.

â—˜ Fair ranking system.
â—˜ After the story has ended, you're able to roam free around the shinobi world along with more missions, requests, and survival.

The only thing I can really not like about this game is the community but I'm not surprised and you shouldn't be either if you have played the rest. But you'll find that only sometimes you'll find worthy opponents to beat fairly and actually enjoy the match.

reviewText:
So after playing this game and completing it I have made a few conclusions:
If you're a Naruto Shippuden fan and follow the series, there is no point to having this game, unless you follow the games also.

if you are new to Naruto Shippuden this is a good series to start to get an idea of what has happened in the anime and manga series, (but if you are unfamiliar to the the original I would suggest looking that up before starting this series) although it doesn't have as much of the content that the anime and manga series contain.

The main purpose of this game is for you to know what is hapening in the series not for an original storyline or amazing gameplay, it's to tell you the story of Naruto Shippuden so expect a hell of a lot of cutscenes, enought that I admit drove me to the point where I stopped playing this for about a month from the bordome of sitting through all of them.

So onto what it does right and wrong, first I'll start with the pros:
-It tells the story really well and does the franchise justice.

-This is one of the very few games that actually make QTE matter as you get rated on how quickly you complete the QTE with stars leading up to a maximum, if you get enough stars you wil get a secret factor which is a couple of shots from the anime and has a little bit of dialogue which is the same in the games 1 and 2 also,

-The music for the boss fights are amazing and the boss fights themselves are handled really well with the rating systems coming in to make it so much better.

-The scenes that want to make to envoke an emotion are outstanding.

-There are changes to the battle system occasionally, where instead of fighting one on one in a circle type arena, you play more like a hack n slash game where you run through different corridors and defeat a number of enemies, it's done alright but it can get annoying after a while.

So now onto the cons:
-There are so many cutscenes, this game seems more like storybook than an actual game, they are also extremely long, wih most being around a good 2 or 3 minutes of just dialogue and nothing exciting happening in them, you'll find yourself skipping them towards the end just cause there was so many, like I did.

-The main battle system is nothing special, it's ripped from the second game this time adding a few more characters that feel different which is good, but it's just kind of bland with each character having a melee combo and one or two jutsu moves depending on how long you hold the attack button. Also some characters have spammable moves that are really cheap whch can get extremely annoying especially if you find someone plaing them online.

-The difficulty spike is awful, unlike ninja storm 2 where the opponents became more difficult over time, this one just has enemies towards the end spamming you with moves you can't dodge and just get overwhelmed with nothng to do about it, and throwing as many enemies as possible at you, either one at a time or all together, neither is fun.

-There is no free roam and most side quests are taken out, once again unlike ninja storm 2 there is no free roaming, the game tells you where to go and you can't do anything to stop it. The side quests have devolved to fetching items for one or two people where you can only get back to them once you complete the game, where you do get to free roam when you complete the game it's not as good due to the sour taste left in your memory having to fight through the main story's corridors.

-The lip synching is laughable, there is no attempt to match the character animation with the english version script. I know it's difficult but it looks like they made no effort with the characters lips still moving for a litle while even after their dialogue is finished (I would suggest to have it in japanese and put on english subtitles, the voice actors are much beter and it looks like the characters are actually talking).

All in all the game isn't bad, but it's nothing special, The story is great (apart from all of the cutscenes) but the combat is nothing out of this world, I would say that if you wanted a better naruto game go back to Ultimate Ninja Storm 2, it was much better done in basically every aspect.
I'm not going to give this game a rating cause that is usually just the person that is reviewing its thought, so I will just say if you enjoy Naruto and want to start Naruto Shippuden but don't feel like going through 350+ of episodes, this game sums it up pretty well.

reviewText:
This is one is very hard to review,I am a Naruto fan...but im reviewing a game not a series.

OK theres one problem here...its not really a game.Theres simply very little gameplay,most of the time your watching the series being beautifully rendered,but during singleplayer thats what you do,there is 127 cut scenes.Those cutscenes are being interrupted by occasional fights or QTE`s or both.So why pay for the game that is basicly a series transfered to your PC when you can just watch the series?

On the fighting system...you use 1 button to perform combos...the other throws projectiles...other jumps...other bust your chakra...and by gathering chakra you perform special attack or ultimate attack..thats it.Yes 1 button to perform a combo...and thats the main attraction of this game...fighting.No,sorry i expected more from a game based on a martial arts anime there is so much more potential,I could forgive it if there would be more gameplay elements,but there arent.Fighting is basicly the main game here and its done pathetic and lazy.

Graphics as i mentioned are great,sounds are taken straight from the series,but thats what i expected anyways.

Its a waste of money,not because its terrible,no,beacuase its not a game,its watching the series all over again.

reviewText: I bought the game DESPITE reading several reviews about how it's a bad port. At first I saw instantly what people were talking about. The game does NOT come with a default keyboard config. I do not know how a game can be released in 2014 without a default config. That essentially means if you tried to instantly hop in a match, no controls will work. Let's also not forget the config diagram that's supposed to help you map out your controls is a diagram of a XBOX controller... yet the game is made for PC. If that's not a sign of a bad port, I don't know what is. HOWEVER, once you map out a decent config on keyboard, the game isn't that bad. The only other issue I have is the framerate being locked at 30 FPS I believe. The other issue being the fact that for some reason, I can't go into full screen mode on this game, while every other game does it fine. Overall, this coming from a naruto fan of 8 years... 6.5/10

Ultimate ninja storm 3 offers a unique combat system when you are not fighting One v One, I call it target switching where you're fighting a group of weak AI, sometimes the game will through bossess" which do heavy attacks and are tougher. reviewText:
Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 throws you into one of Naruto lore's most titanic battles right from the start. Without any preamble you find yourself clashing with the 20-story-tall Nine-Tailed Demon Fox as he ravages Naruto's home village. Except it isn't Naruto's home village, because he hasn't been born yet. Because this is, at last, the series' cataclysmic battle from the past that's been teased for years, but never fully shown before. It's a great first impression, and it sets the pace for the best Ultimate Ninja Storm to date.
...And you're flung straight into it. First as Naruto's father, who must face off against the masked mastermind controlling the gigantic beast, and then as the Third Hokage in a breathtaking, intense battle that's fought leaping from rooftop to rooftop, circling around this monstrously large terror, coordinating with fellow ninja to hold the creature at bay. This series has pushed its visual spectacle to new heights with every installment, but itâ€™s in moments like this that UNS3 proves to be the most epic and most fanservice-packed.
When youâ€™ve finally managed to take down the Demon Fox, thereâ€™s no chance to catch your breath â€“ because youâ€™re then flung right back to Naruto's dad, still in the middle of his own fight. UNS3 bounces around like this dynamically. You can be halfway through a major clash, then the focus will shift to another battlefield or point in time and have you fight a second, simultaneous fight before circling you back around to your starting point. It's a brilliant break from tradition that constantly keeps your attention focused and your energy up. It could've gone wrong and been distracting, but since each instance is interwoven with the storyline and serves a plot-advancing purpose, I never felt like I was bounced around for no reason.
For the most part, this is the same Ninja Storm combat as before â€“ just a bit faster. Ultimate Ninja Storm 3's feels as if the controls have gotten tighter and more responsive, which was appreciated as I ran, dodged, and teleported my way around each 3D battleground trying to gain a positional advantage over my opponent. Some mechanics introduced in earlier installments have been tweaked, too, like the fact that you can now enter your character's Awakened" state without waiting until their health bar has been depleted to the edge of death.
Things are a bit easier
date: too. UNS3's difficulty settings seem muted
recommended: as few fights will offer a true challenge to anyone who's bested any of the earlier games. The most elite players will have to seek out high-level opponents online
hoursPlayed: because the AI won't keep up with you.\nAt some points during the story
voteText: UNS3 offers some confusing decisions about which of two paths you want to follow. They're presented as a choice between the "Legend" path or the "Hero" path
helpfulPercent: but aren't both of those good things? I suppose being a "Legend" is more epic than just being a plain old "Hero
votesHelpful:
but it's odd phrasing â€“ and it's made even more perplexing because you earn either Legend Points or Hero Points for picking one over the other, and the distinction between those is never adequately explained.
Experimenting with picking different story paths does open up unique cutscenes and fights not previously seen on the cartoon, though, so the confusion is worth enduring. In the opening clash against the Nine-Tailed Fox, for instance, you get to witness Choza Akimichi grow to Godzilla-like proportions and bodyslam the 20-story beast. So it's worth experimenting with, at least.
Other than that, as with the earlier Ultimate Ninja Storm games, this one sticks pretty close to retelling the cartoon's plots point for point. Those decision moments are your opportunity to deviate a bit, which keeps things from being a total retread. Youâ€™re ultimately funneled back to the core timeline after having witnessed the extra, side content, so the decisions are never too earth-shattering â€“ you canâ€™t end up picking a path where Naruto dies or anything like that.
Some fans will no doubt take issue with the story's ending in this installment, as it's non-canonical and probably not a reflection of what will be seen in the show. Alternate story paths diverging from the events of older episodes are fun what if?" scenarios worth taking a look at. But when UNS3 starts projecting out past the scope of currently aired TV episodes and currently published manga to invent its own vision of Naruto's future
votesTotal: the waters get a little choppy.\nOne area that disappointed was the limited exploration in story mode â€“ we're teased with free-roaming areas every once in awhile
votesFunny: but they never amount to much and you're quickly shuffling back into watching the next sequence of cutscenes. Also: do we really need all Fuu the Insect Girl as a playable character? We have over 80 now â€“ it's probably safe to stop scraping the bottom of that barrel.\n\nEven if the difficulty skews toward the easy side

column19: overrides my concerns about non-canon story choices and lets us have fun with "what if" scenarios. Ultimate Ninja Storm's reputation as Naruto's most consistently enjoyable game series is safe."

reviewText:
As someone who isn't in deep into the Naruto lore here, I'll try and give a brief summary of what you'll be getting with your purchase:

You'll get a fighting game that, compared to the 6 button combo-fighters you'll find out there, is relatively simple. Its easy to learn (although the in-game tutorials are not exactly helpful), and I can imagine it gets pretty deep the more time you invest.

To the best of my knowledge, the story is interesting and carries itself based on how much you like the franchise. Not to say there isn't anything here for new comers, but you'll definitely get your moneys worth if you know the story.

However, the characters from a superficial samepoint all feel samey, and a lot of characters need to be unlocked in the story mode (which combines the one on one fighting with horde fighting), and that gives some incentive to playing the game in full. Theres a sort of morality system too: you choose between legend scenarios (ones that are generally shows of strength and power in the story) and hero scenarios (think mass effect paragon.) that give the story minor replayability, and allow you to level up these respective attributes. (For the most part, if you're looking for a challenge, you'll find yourself picking legend as unscrupulous as is despite your personal feelings on the matter.)

Well, what else can I say? Good art direction, plenty of things for fans, online play, fun, pick-up-and-play action, you could do worse. I would wait for a sale, though, if you aren't in the fanbase already.

Nice Game. The Combat isn't hard to get used to, but I prefer that rather than mortal Kombat or Street Fighter that takes forever to memorize all the combos and abilities of each character. If you enjoy Dragonball Z : Budokai 1-3 then you should check this game out.

I recommend it, I even already Pre-ordered the next game coming out.

reviewText:
A Very Nice Anime Game.

The Fighting is not too complicate to control and give the Feeling of Awesomeness like the Anime.

Totally playable with Keyboard, (Key bind setting in the launcher) But Controllers are recommended. (I play with Keyboard All this time)

Hours of Story Mode (~80% watching ~20% playing) Then Exploring the world afterwards, collect the history pages and Fight battles of the past. There are Some QTE in Story mode that rewards Special Cutscenes during the story gameplay.
Some of the story battle might feels a bit lacking something (like the Beasts fight)

Also There's [Online Play] to test your Ninja skills Online. (Havn't try it much yet)
And Free Fight mode where you can fight Locally or fight with A.I. or just Practice.

Overall I think This game is worth its cost. Totally.

Edit : PS. I've never read or Watch Naruto before playing this game. (of course i've seen it sometimes) But after playing this game I feel like i want to.
